docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Miami gave final approval yesterday to an agreement between Aetna, the big health insurer, and nearly one million doctors to end a longrunning dispute dispute over patient care and billing practices. The judge, Federico Moreno of Federal District Court, said that the agreement intended to speed payments, to provide clearer information on coverage for both patients and doctors and to reduce red tape was an ''excellent result.''

headline.main: Judge Approves Plan to Settle Doctors' Dispute With Aetna

docs.abstract: Judge Federico Moreno gives final approval to agreement between Aetna, health insurer, and nearly one million doctors to end longrunning dispute over patient care and billing practices (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress will create a mechanism to slow the growth of Medicare spending when it adds drug benefits to the health insurance program for the elderly, the chairman of a panel writing the law said on Friday. The chairman, Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, said House and Senate negotiators were devising such a mechanism to ensure that the program was fiscally sustainable. Without it, Mr. Thomas said, the final measure cannot win approval in the House, which passed the original bill by one vote in June.

headline.main: Congress Planning to Curb Growth of Medicare Budget

docs.abstract: Republican Rep Bill Thomas, who is chairman of panel on Medicare, says Congress is creating mechanism to slow growth of Medicare spending when it adds drug coverage to health insurance program; Congress has set aside $400 billion over 10 years for new drug benefits; conservative Republicans say they will not vote for Medicare bill that includes drug benefits unless cost-control measures are in place (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Every night for months, Victor Zavala Jr., who was arrested on Thursday in a 21-state immigration raid, said he showed up at the Wal-Mart store in New Jersey to clean floors. As the store's regular employees left at 11 p.m., Mr. Zavala said, they often asked him whether he ever got a night off.

headline.main: Cleaner at Wal-Mart Tells of Few Breaks and Low Pay

docs.abstract: Victor Zavala Jr, who is arrested as illegal alien from Mexico, feels cheated for having worked as hard as he could to pursue the American dream, only to face deportation; Wal-Mart pays him $400 to work 56 hours per week, equaling $6.25 per hour, with no days off or benefits; is one of 250 janitors employed by Wal-Mart who is arrested; federal officials believe Wal-Mart knew contractors were illegal; Wal-Mart officials say they are beginning internal investigation; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after Republican negotiators said they had reached a tentative agreement on a prescription drug benefit for the elderly, Senate Democrats said on Thursday that the benefit could be in jeopardy if House Republicans insisted on a plan forcing the traditional Medicare program to compete directly with private health plans. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the the drug benefit was ''at grave risk at this time'' because House Republicans were pushing the Medicare bill in a conservative direction.

headline.main: Democrats Say G.O.P. Endangers Medicare Drug Accord

docs.abstract: Senate Democrats say prescription drug benefit for elderly could be in jeopardy if House Republicans insist on plan forcing traditional Medicare program to compete directly with private health plans; 41 senators sign letter to Pres Bush urging him to intervene in Medicare negotations, to ensure that final bill could win bipartisan support; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Net Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, said it agreed to pay $137 million to settle a lawsuit over the 1998 sale of a workers compensation business that was later taken over by state regulators. The suit, brought by the Superior National Insurance Group three years ago, was scheduled for trial next month. The cost of the settlement reduced Health Net's third-quarter net income, the company said. The lawsuit sought $300 million in compensatory damages and unspecified punitive awards related to the sale of the Business Insurance Group, Health Net said in an Aug. 11 regulatory filing. Superior claimed that Health Net made misleading statements about Business Insurance's financial reserves.

headline.main: HEALTH NET AGREES TO PAY $137 MILLION TO SETTLE SUIT

docs.abstract: California's Health Net Inc agrees to pay $137 million to settle lawsuit over sale of workers compensation business that was later taken over by state regulators; suit was brought by Superior National Insurance Group three years ago (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American International Group, one of the world's biggest insurers, reported a nearly 27 percent increase in net income for the third quarter, as prices for its insurance have been rising and claims costs have been declining. ''Cash flow has been terrific,'' the chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, said in a conference call with analysts.

headline.main: A.I.G. Says Net Rose 27% in Quarter

docs.abstract: American International Group reports nearly 27 percent increase in net income for third quarter; net income rose to $2.34 billion from $1.84 billion yer earlier; cash flow was record $3.58 billion from $2.5 billion year ago; chief executive Maurice R Greenberg says company has struck deal with People's Insurance Co of China to sell AIG's accident and health insurance throughout country; says he doubts legislation to establish fund intended to end most litigation over health damages caused by asbestos will be adopted this year, partly because of union demands that insurers increase their proposed contribution; notes rating agency A M Best raised ranking of AIG's American units to its highest level and says that can only help sales; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the statewide political landscape, Suffolk ranks as the most populous county outside New York City and has been a vaunted Republican stronghold. But a major coup looms in the Nov. 4 election as Democrats appear in reach of capturing control of its county government. The campaign for county executive has evolved into a clash between the alter egos of Brookhaven and ''Crookhaven.'' Brookhaven is the giant town that dominates Suffolk, and ''Crookhaven'' is the nickname coined for its reputation for scandal.

headline.main: Democrats Smell Victory In Suffolk Executive Race

docs.abstract: Democrats are optimistic that Steve Levy can win county executive election in Suffolk County, NY; county and its largest town, Brookhaven, are longtime Republican strongholds, but several prominent corruption allegations and convictions have shaken confidence in party; Edward P Romaine, Republican candidate, says he is reformer who will set things straight; photos (M)

Beloved father of Mark, Gary, Glenn, Luanne & Patricia. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jonathon, Vanessa, Michele, Billy & Christine. Friends may visit The Alexander-Tuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Rte. 25A, Wading River, Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Private.

docs.lead_paragraph: The WebMD Corporation, which operates health information Web sites and manages transactions between doctors and insurers, has agreed to buy Medifax-EDI for $280 million to improve its data collection ability. The cash-and-debt deal is expected to close late next month, WebMD said. Medifax-EDI, which is closely held and based in Nashville, provides services that help verify insurance coverage for patients quickly and will be combined with WebMD's Envoy unit, it said. WebMD has spent $400 million in 12 months on acquisitions while shedding other assets to focus on its primary businesses.

headline.main: WEBMD TO PAY $280 MILLION FOR MEDIFAX-EDI

docs.abstract: WebMD Corp, which operates health information Web sites and manages transactions between doctors and insurers, agrees to buy Medifax-EDI for $280 million to improve its data collection ability (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert N. Serros was one of those entrepreneurs who see opportunity everywhere but take a long time to grasp it. They are the people who plunge into one money-making venture after another, never quite hitting their stride until, at long last, inspiration strikes and everything falls into place. For Mr. Serros, 37, who today presides over Amber Diagnostics, an $8 million company in Orlando, Fla., it took years and goading from his wife before the light bulb came on.

headline.main: Taking a While to Heed Opportunity's Knock

docs.abstract: Article on entrepreneur Robert N Serros's various small business ventures that finally led to presiding over Amber Diagnostics, $8 million company in Orlando, Fla, which sells used medical equipment directly to hospitals and doctors; Serros comments; chart; photo (M)
